msContents.summary:
At the beginning of the seventeenth century, beginning in eastern Switzerland, the first Collegia Musica were founded, musical associations originally connected with Psalm singing. In Berne, Collegia Musica were founded in the second half of the seventeenth century, with the decisive influence of cornett player and music director Johann Ulrich Sultzberger. A Collegium Musicum is first mentioned in Bern in 1672 in the town's regulations for music ('Ordnung'). At that time, the founding of a new association needed the approval from the authorities. Sultzberger founded his own Collegium Musicum probably in 1675, consisting of students from the High School. This Collegium Musicum is mentioned for the first time in 1677.
The records of the sessions of the Berne Board of Education ('Schulrats Manual') contains in the second volume (1696–1701) on fols 21v-22v a directory that lists instruments and musical works of the student Collegium Musicum. The inventory contains 32 entries for music and 6 items for instruments.
The inventory provides an insight into the musical culture of the time. Sacred and secular works are balanced in number. Besides well known musicians such as Orlando di Lasso and Johann Rosenmüller, a large number of less known contemporary composers is listed.
